bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to John Carter, July 13, 1720

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to his son John, then in London studying law, on July 13, 1720, complaining at length about John's expenses, particularly in persuading Micajah Perry to advance him funds beyond his allowance. He states that if John deceives him again about the expenses, he will no longer accept John's word about the management of his affairs in London. He continues by refuting John's claim that John Randolph has maligned John, and adds that Randolph never wore better clothes that he has observed although his acquaintance with Randolph is slight. Randolph's politics and his were so opposed, Randolph being "a rank Torey a Proud, humble Parasite a fawning Sycophant to his Patron," that he had not hired Randolph again after a year of retaining him, and now finds Randolph involved in almost all cases he has lost. Robert continues that his lawsuit against Thomas Wise should soon be concluded, and that he will write separately concering "Mr. Lee's Settlemt. & Sr. Robt. Raymond's opinion upon the Case." He writes John some information "Mr. Cary's Lawsuit is not Yett determin'd" and gives some details of the case, and notes that some poor familys that "whose Ancestors before them have liv'd & Dyed in quiet possession of these Lands" are likely to be hurt by the suit, adding that he has a closer claim to the lands than the person from whom Cary acquired because they had belonged to his niece. He instructs John to visit Cary and make him acquainted with these facts, reporting that he had made offers to Cary through his lawyers to buy the lands in question, and directing John to keep in close contact, pressing Cary for his "Lowest Demands." He concludes by criticising John for not mentioning his brothers who are in England at school, and reports that the family is well.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to John Carter, July 13, 1720
div1.p:
Yors. of the 15th of Feb. came lately to my hands in It
You make me a great many promisses to make no farther use of
my money Beyond the Allowance I have agreed to give You &
Indeed tis a p[ie]s[e]. of very extraordinary managemt. In Mr. Perry
to give yo[u] the opportunity of doing It. Tho I have Yor. frequent
promisses for a Stated Accot. of Yor. Expenses You leave me
As much in the Dark as ever, You Engage Yor Self Indeed
upon more full mouthd promisses for a bettr. regulation
a Closer applicatn to Yor. Studys & a greater frugality for the
Future, but w[ha]t. reason have I to believe You'll be more Consistent
wth. Yor. word now than You have hitherto bin, however I will once
more lay somew[ha]t. upon w[ha]t. You say is Yor. fix'd resolution but
If you deceive me again I must be so plain to tell You—
I Shall have little Dependance upon w[ha]t. You say hereafter
In relation to the managemt. governmt of Yor. self—

You seem to Suspect Mr. Randolph hath Done You
Some Disservice in his character of You but in that You are
Entirely Mistaken I Dont know nor ever heard he hath
lett fall any Expression to Yor. Disadvantage nor Indeed had
I Ever much Discourse wth. him abt. You, so that If he's under any
obligation to You, he is for w[ha]t. I know clear of the Sin of
Ingratitude. as for his wearing finer Linnen or finer Cloths
Than You he never appeard in any Such here that I
have seen, my Accquaintance wth. him is very slender
only now and then casualy at a Dinner, his Principles
& mine are of a very Diff[eren]t nature a rank Torey a
Proud, humble Parasite a fawning Sycophant to his
Patron wth. all the other requisites to a servile Courtier. These
are as much reverse to my nature as white is to black
besides altho he was my Servant for a year & I gave him a retaining fee at his first
coming in he hath bin in all Causes That I have had against me
From whence You may conclude there is very little
familiarity between us.

Mr. Richd. Perry tells me he should Settle Mr. Wise's
Affair in a Short time, Mr. Lee's Settlemt. & Sr. Robt. Raymond's
opinion upon the Case I Shall Consider in a Lettr. by Itself.

Mr. Cary's Lawsuit is not Yett determin'd altho I
take the Difficultyst part of It to be over It is come to the
Issue The last Jury made two Surveys & have submitted It
to the Judgement of the Court w[hi]ch. of the two Surveys is the
right such a proceeding in a Jury I never Saw before but it
lyes upon this Issue for Tryal to the next Court. lett the Determination
be as much in the Disfavour of Mr. Cary as It can
he'l have Enough for his money, & in my Conscience I think
of right he ought to go no further than the Inmost lines If
he recovers to the outer most It will be a very hard fate
to Sevl. Poor familys whose Ancestors before them have
liv'd & Dyed in quiet possession of these Lands, & If Cary be a
Man of honour & Circumstance I believe If he were
upon the Spott he would be contented to take his land
wth.out Disturbing these poor people. I'm sure w[ere] he in
right mind I would Forthwith give It up, & If Proximity
of blood might take place, I am a nearer heir than the
Person Cary Purchasd from, Those Lands were the Inhe=
=ritance of my Bro[the]rs Daughter and she dy'd last Seizd
of That Inheritance, I'd have you acquaint Mr. Cary
wth this whole Storey. he hath fee'd indeed all the
Lawyers that are of any value in the Country How farr
the Strength of Lungs may go in bewildering A Court
& worrying Poor men out of their rights I Cant tell
You might very well Smile at Cary's taulking of £3000
when he bought. those Lands & two considerable Tracts more
as I take It for less than 500, I offer'd his Lawyers
At the barr to take the Land wth.in the Inmost bounds & to
pay him his principal money & Interest from the
time of the Paymt. wth. the Charges of the Lawsuit
& £100 besides for his bargain. or If this will not do
I Shall be willing to give him as much for It as
any body else & I think the relationship should make
him So Generous rather to lett me have It than another
I would have you keep the business warm between You
& to Accquaint me wth. his Lowest Demands. There
is but one Difficulty in the Wind wch. If I can gett over
I may make a better Title to these lands than any of
the heirs of Hull under whom Cary purchast—

In all Yor Long Lettr. You forgett to Say one
Syllable of Yor Bro[the]rs Surely they are more in Yor care
Than all this comes to. Yor Sisters & their familys are in
health my Daughr Page wth her husband went from
hence but two Days ago we all Enjoy health in this
family at this time thank God I commit You to the
Protection of the Almighty & am

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1720 July-1721 July, BR 227, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, San Marino, California. Printed: Wright. Letters of Robert Carter. . . . pp. 7-10.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence to merchants abroad. The county and state have been added for clarity.

[1] RC and Thomas Wise had "traded with each other in tobacco and bills of exchange between 1707 and 1717," but Wise "neglected his duty in returning those bills that were protested." Carter sued Wise in England to recover his money, and he won £180. (Survey Report 10147 describing C24/1398 part 1, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert H. Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia; and letter of August 19, 1723, RC to Micajah Perry.)
[2] Sir Robert Raymond, later Lord Chief Justice, was Attorney General in 1720. He was regarded as the foremost lawyer of his day.

[3] Elizabeth (Carter) Lloyd (1675-1693) was RC's brother John's only child. Elizabeth married John Lloyd in 1691, and was dead by November 1693 of measles. John appointed managers of the estate in 1699 in Essex County, and returned to England the next year as he had inherited land there. Elizabeth inherited from her mother, Elizabeth Hull, also an only child, all of her grandfather John Hull's property.
[4] Probably Richard Hull of Northumberland County who died in 1717.

[5] John Carter's younger brothers, Robert (1704-1732), Charles (1707-1764), and Landon (1710-1778), were then in England for their education. (Greene, The Diary of Colonel Landon Carter of Sabine Hall,1752-1778, 3.)
[6] John's sister Judith (1695-c.1750) who married Mann Page of "Rosewell" in 1718.

[7] Mr. Cary may have been Robert Cary (1685-1751), a member of a British family of merchants who had many Virginia connections. See Price. "Who Was John Norton? A Note on . . . Some Eighteenth-Century London Virginia Firms." for an extensive discussion of the Cary family.
